Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Alignment in the Grammar of Tupari, an Endangered Language of the Brazilian Amazon

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One reason that linguists seek to investigate a wide variety of languages is because even basic sentences can behave in radically different ways. So while English is often thought of as having subjects and objects that work with verbs to create sentences, linguists have shown a much larger range of ways that subjects behave, especially in terms of their relationships to the verb and the roles they play in sentences. For example, some subjects are the agent of the action, such as "She saw the cat," others are patients of the action, as in "The ball was thrown by the boy," and some subjects are empty placeholders, such as the "it" in "It is important that you study math." Languages show a wide variety of approaches for how these subject roles and object roles pattern, and some of these patterns are quite rare. Documenting and analyzing these kinds of patterns, which linguists call "alignment", is important for a larger understanding of the cross-linguistic variation in human grammar. This dissertation will add deeper insight to the less frequent type of patterns ("typology").

In this dissertation project, doctoral student Adam Roth Singerman will document the grammar of Tupari, an endangered language spoken by perhaps 300 people in villages in the Rio Branco Indigenous Reserve, in the Brazilian state of Rondônia. Working closely with the community, Singerman will first document a wide variety of interesting grammatical phenomena in Tupari. This theory-neutral description of the language's morphosyntax will serve as the basis for the first complete reference grammar of the language. It will also create a foundation for more detailed, theoretical investigation into several key topics, focusing especially on the grammatical alignment patterns (both ergative-absolutive and nominative-accusative) which Tupari shows. Alignment in Tupari behaves in ways that defy previous generalizations from the literature, so studying it in greater depth is important for typological research and for syntactic theory. In addition to creating a comprehensive, complete description of Tupari grammar, Singerman will also collaborate with the community to develop native literacy materials. The dissertation will also facilitate comparative analysis of the Tupian family, drawing from languages of Rondônia that are historically related to Tupari, including Gavião, Mekens, and Karitiâna.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG) from the NSF's Documenting Endangered Languages Program has contributed to the long-term documentation of the Tuparí language, which is spoken by approximately 350 indigenous residents of the Brazilian state of Rondônia. Like many other Native peoples of Brazil, the Tuparí face strong pressures to assimilate, culturally and linguistically, into non-indigenous society. Our efforts to document the Tuparí language have been carried out in partnership with the Native schoolteachers and the political leadership of the Rio Branco Indigenous Reserve, who seek to ensure that a lasting record of the language is available for future generations. Our work with the Tuparí people parallels comparable efforts to document and revitalize indigenous languages that have been undertaken in many other parts of the Americas, including here in the United States.

 

This DDRIG has led to the production of several academic works that will contribute to the long-term documentation of the Tuparí language. First, Adam Singerman produced an extensive description and analysis of Tuparí grammar as his doctoral dissertation (successfully defended at the University of Chicago in summer 2018). This dissertation is available for free online. Second, Singerman has published articles on Tuparí grammar in two journals: Language and The International Journal of American Linguistics. Third, Singerman has created a large corpus of materials on the Tuparí language, including a sizable set of non-elicited utterances drawn from spontaneous conversation. This corpus has been archived at The Archive of the Indigenous Languages of Latin America at the University of Texas, Austin, where it will remain accessible for future researchers and others interested in Tuparí.

 

In the spring of 2019, Singerman was awarded a new research fellowship from the Documenting Endangered Languages Program to conduct follow-up field research with the Tuparí people and to write a comprehensive reference grammar of their language. This work will take place between July 2020 and July 2021 and will build directly upon what has been accomplished through the DDRIG. It will result in publications of interest to the English-speaking public (in particular, the reference grammar of Tuparí) and will also contribute to local language maintenance initiatives: during the fellowship period, Singerman will work with Native Tuparí schoolteachers to produce bilingual Tuparí-Portuguese materials that can be useful for the residents of the Rio Branco Indigenous Reserve.

 

In terms of broader impacts, this project contributes to efforts to document Native cultures and languages of South America — with a serious focus on long-term cultural and linguistic vitality and survival. We believe that this kind of work is especially important given the accelerating destruction of the Amazon Rainforest, which attracted new international attention during the summer of 2019. The long-term survival of the Tuparí people — and of the hundreds of other Native nations who reside in the Amazon Basin — is threatened by deforestation and other activities that damage the environment. Carefully documenting indigenous cultures and languages is a way to publicly affirm the value of Native Amazonian peoples and to highlight the catastrophic human costs of runaway environmental destruction.
